# Abstract

Introduce the ContractFactory type in ethers.js and use it to deploy contracts. For details, please refer to the [ethers.js documentation](https://docs.ethers.org/v5/api/contract/contract-factory/)

## Deploy Contract

On Ethereum, the deployment of a smart contract is a special transaction: the bytecode compiled from the smart contract is sent to address 0. If the constructor of this contract has parameters,
you need to use abi.encode to encode the parameters into bytecode, and then attach them to the end of the contract bytecode and send them together.

## Contract Factory

**ethers.js** creates the **ContractFactory** type to facilitate developers to deploy contracts. You can use the contract abi, the compiled bytecode bytecode and the signer variable signer to create a contract factory instance to prepare for contract deployment.
```
const contractFactory = new ethers.ContractFactory(abi, bytecode, signer)
```

After creating the contract factory instance, you can call its deploy function and pass in the contract constructor parameter args to deploy and obtain the contract instance:
```
const contract = await contractFactory.deploy(args)
```

You can use the following two commands to wait for the contract deployment to be confirmed on the chain before interacting.
```
await contractERC20.waitForDeployment()
```

## Example: Deploy an ERC20 token contract

1. Create provider and wallet variables.

```
import { ethers } from "ethers";

// Use Alchemy's rpc node to connect to the Ethereum network
const ALCHEMY_GOERLI_URL = 'https://eth-goerli.alchemyapi.io/v2/GlaeWuylnNM3uuOo-SAwJxuwTdqHaY5l';
const provider = new ethers.JsonRpcProvider(ALCHEMY_GOERLI_URL);

// Create a wallet object using the private key and provider
const privateKey = '0x227dbb8586117d55284e26620bc76534dfbd2394be34cf4a09cb775d593b6f2b'
const wallet = new ethers.Wallet(privateKey, provider)
```

2. Prepare the bytecode and ABI of the ERC20 contract. Because the ERC20 constructor has parameters, we must include it in the ABI. The bytecode of the contract can be copied from the compilation panel of remix by clicking the Bytecode button,
   where the data corresponding to the "object" field is the bytecode. If the contract is deployed on the chain, you can find it in the Contract Creation Code on the Contract page of etherscan.

```
// Human readable abi of ERC20
const abiERC20 = [
  "constructor(string memory name_, string memory symbol_)",
  "function name() view returns (string)",
  "function symbol() view returns (string)",
  "function totalSupply() view returns (uint256)",
  "function balanceOf(address) view returns (uint)",
  "function transfer(address to, uint256 amount) external returns (bool)",
  "function mint(uint amount) external",
];
// Fill in the contract bytecode. In remix, you can find Bytecode in two places.
// 1. Compile the Bytecode button of the panel
// 2. In the json file with the same name as the contract in the artifact folder of the file panel
// The data corresponding to the "object" field under the "bytecode" attribute is the Bytecode, which is quite long and starts at 608060 ...

const bytecodeERC20 = ""
```

![compileERC20_bytecode](https://github.com/wls503pl/Ethers/blob/main/DeployContract/img/compileERC20_bytecode.png)<br>

![object_bytecode](https://github.com/wls503pl/Ethers/blob/main/DeployContract/img/object_bytecode.png)<br>


If the contract is deployed on the chain, you can find it in the Contract Creation Code on the Contract page of etherscan. I won’t go into details here.

3. Create a contract factory **ContractFactory** instance.

```
const factoryERC20 = new ethers.ContractFactory(abiERC20, bytecodeERC20, wallet);
```

4. Call the ***deploy()*** function of the factory contract and fill in the ***constructor*** parameters (token name and symbol) to deploy the ERC20 token contract and obtain the contract instance. You can use:
- **contract.target**: Get the contract address.
- **contract.deployTransaction**: Get deployment details.
- **contractERC20.waitForDeployment()**: Wait for the contract deployment to be confirmed on the chain.

```
// 1. Use contractFactory to deploy ERC20 token contract
console.log("\n1. Use contractFactory to deploy ERC20 token contract")
// Deploy the contract and fill in the constructor parameters
const contractERC20 = await factoryERC20.deploy("WTF Token", "WTF")
console.log(`Contract address: ${contractERC20.target}`);
console.log("deployment contract transaction details")
console.log(contractERC20.deploymentTransaction())
console.log("\nWaiting for contract deployment on chain")
await contractERC20.waitForDeployment()
// You can also use contractERC20.deployTransaction.wait()
console.log("The contract has been uploaded")
```

5. After the contract is on the chain, call the ***name()*** and ***symbol()*** functions to print the token **name** and **symbol**, and then call the ***mint()*** function to mint 10,000 tokens for yourself.

```
// Print the contract's name() and symbol(), then call the mint() function to mint 10,000 tokens to your own address
console.log("\n2. Call the mint() function to mint 10,000 tokens to your own address")
console.log(`Contract name: ${await contractERC20.name()}`)
console.log(`Contract symbol: ${await contractERC20.symbol()}`)
let tx = await contractERC20.mint("10000")
console.log("Waiting for transaction to be uploaded")
await tx.wait()
console.log(`Balance of tokens in the address after mint: ${await contractERC20.balanceOf(wallet)}`)
console.log(`Total supply of tokens: ${await contractERC20.totalSupply()}`)
```

6. Call the ***transfer()*** function to transfer 1,000 tokens to Vitalik

```
// Call the transfer() function to transfer 1000 tokens to Vitalik
console.log("\n3. Call transfer() function to transfer 1,000 tokens to Vitalik")
tx = await contractERC20.transfer("vitalik.eth", "1000")
console.log("Waiting for transaction to be uploaded")
await tx.wait()
console.log(`Token balance in Vitalik's wallet: ${await contractERC20.balanceOf("vitalik.eth")}`)
```
